awd_titl_txt: Unsuspected eukaryotic life inhabits rhodolith-forming coralline algae (Hapalidiales, Rhodophyta), a remarkable marine benthic microhabitat
awd_abstract_narration:
Rhodoliths are unattached crust-forming marine macroalgae (seaweeds) called corallines that are common in the northwestern Gulf of Mexico and they are the main foundation for the attachment of other marine life at 45-90 meter depth. This research will significantly increase our knowledge of algal diversity. It will also assess whether rodoliths may function as temporary reservoirs for life history stages of ecologically and economically important microalgae (seedbanks), or as a safe refuge for species following environmental stress. The findings will open the door to assess the universality of bloom-forming microalgae, some of which are of public health concerns, and are found inside rhodoliths in marine ecosystems around the world. This project will provide training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students as well as a post-doctoral researcher and high school students, with attention to underrepresented groups. Additionally, the investigators will develop unique outreach programs for the public, and will make all data collected available to the scientific community and the general public to enable broad-scale comparative analyses and integration with other data sets. These products will be important for the fields of marine algal biology, ecology, fisheries and biotourism.

The research will characterize the rhodolith microhabitat biota with plastid tufA, 16S V4 and 23S UPA metabarcoding (amplicon-based environmental sequencing) assays specifically targeting primary producers using high-throughput sequencing against reference datasets. The study will also augment reference datasets for various molecular markers through Sanger sequencing of Gulf algae for facilitated identification of taxa recovered in the metabarcoding assays. In addition, monographic research of various groups of algae and an illustrated field guide of rhodolith-associated phototrophs will be produced.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Drs. Suzanne Fredericq (PI, University of Louisiana at Lafayette) and Sherry Krayesky-Self (Co-PI, University of Louisiana at Lafayette) completed research based on unique offshore marine hard bank habitats associated and dominated by unattached red algal (rhodolith) beds surmounting salt domes at 45-90m depth in the northwestern Gulf of Mexico. These beds were found to be extremely diversity-rich in both number of rhodoliths and other algal species. During the funding period, the two research laboratories accomplished extensive offshore field collections, voucher processing, molecular characterization and analyses of algae associated with rhodoliths, description of multiple species, SEM (and FIB-SEM) and TEM microscopy, and microcosm maintenance of live algae collected during the offshore field trips. Molecular investigation emphasized sampling and preservation of material for subsequent analysis of DNA sequences for barcoding, phylogenetic and biogeographical studies. DNA barcoding demonstrated the importance of rhodoliths for macroalgal ecology and biodiversity in Gulf of Mexico offshore habitats. The research demonstrated that the interior of rhodoliths are marine biodiversity hotspots that may function as seedbanks in state of dormancy (cryptobiosis) for macroalgae and as temporary reservoirs of previously unknown stages in the life history of microalgae. The research also indicated that internal life history stages of microalgae inside rhodolith cells may be much more common than is currently understood and that they are of critical importance for understanding algal community cycling (life cycle completion, regeneration, resilience). Since 16S is universally amplified across pro- and eukaryotic diversity, additional datasets generated allowed exploration of linking prokaryotic and algal diversity in rhodolith microbiota. Combination of 16S Sanger sequencing of “visible” algal taxa with cutting-edge 16S metabarcoding of “invisible,” hidden stages/organisms in rhodolith microbiota and adjacent water column helped realize an exhaustive biodiversity assessment of algal communities found in the rhodolith habitats. Metabarcoding research has opened the door to assess the universality of endolithic interactions by bloom-forming microalgae spanning many different phyla in marine ecosystems worldwide. The research has shown the importance to study historical samples to assess future shifts in communities in space and time, effects of global warming, ocean acidification on calcifying organisms. The research has laid the foundation of understanding the contribution of rhodoliths in understanding large-scale ecosystem processes such as community structure and biogeochemical cycles and to unravel the complexity of the rhodolith holobiont, microbial and predator-prey interactions, symbiotic associations, characterization of the transfer of nutrients and energy. We learned that a great tragedy (an oil spill) can open up new and exciting research avenues and approaches for studying algal ecology and biodiversity. The research did up speed and further invigorate systematic phycology.

 

The results of this project are available in multiple publications. The project provided multiple training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as high school students, with attention to underrepresented groups. High school teacher education focused on the inclusion of algae into high school biology curricula; on-site high school and grade school visits with students’ hands-on interaction with marine algae; implementation of a Dual Enrollment course, providing the coordination for the University’s Academic Mentoring Matters; and the newly implemented university-wide Advance (a new Student Research Experience Program at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette).

The co-PI was hired as the Director of the new University Student Center for Research in 2021 and oversees the implementation of the University’s Quality Enhancement Plan, a ten-year commitment directly tied to the University’s accreditation and strategic plan. The goals include increasing undergraduate research and outreach at UL Lafayette, changing the culture at the university so that faculty and students understand the value of research as an educational tool and increasing dissemination of undergraduate student research across campus. The co-PI continues to work with the Lafayette parish school system as well as private high schools in the Lafayette area. While covid-19 had a large and negative impact on summer programs and single day, in-person events, it did not negatively affect the dual enrollment program. The biology dual enrollment course now includes two schools - a public and a private school. Laboratory experiences that include algae are presented to these students and their teachers with the result that a lot of students become excited to learn about aspects of phycology they never imagined existed. Biology undergraduate students, including REU students, combined hands-on fieldwork and practical application of modern techniques and were mentored in molecular phylogenetics and algal morphology that included research presentations at multiple avenues and publications.
